title: MAMBO Pop Up
history: The story of the Bogota Museum of Modern Art MAMBO
historyDescription:
In 1953, General Gustavo Rojas Pinilla mounted a military coup, establishing a dictatorship that restricted the rights and freedoms of the citizens of Colombia. Nevertheless, during this period important steps were taken in the modernisation of the country. One of these was a decree leading to the creation of the Museum of Modern Art, signed in 1955 by a group comprising intellectuals, artists and government ministers. 

 The Museum existed for several years without a permanent site. During this time, it occupied various venues, including the National University and the District Planetarium. The critic and administrator Marta Traba was a driving force behind opening the Museum to the public from 1962, until 1967, when she was expelled from the country for her objection to military intervention at the National University, where the Museum was then based. Gloria Zea took over as director when the Museum left the university campus, managing various sites until the acquisition in 1974, of the plot on which the present building now stands. Construction began in 1979 and was completed in 1985 (Zea, 1994, pp.50-78).n
 Today, MAMBO is situated in the centre of the city, neighbouring both the Parque Bicentenario and the Parque de la Independencia and within easy walking distance of the District Planetarium. It is housed in a building designed by Colombian architect Rogelio Salmona, based on the principles of abstract art, and modern architecture in Bogotá (Moreno y Medina,1994, pp.88-92).n
 MAMBO has worked for 57 years in the research, preservation and promotion of modern and contemporary art. The artist Claudia Hakim took over as director in 2016, heading a new team with aims to work with the general public on a variety of projects involving curatorship, museography, and education.
author: Oscar Monsalve
authorContent: Oscar Monsalve, the museum’s first official photographer, built an important visual record of modern and contemporary art in Colombia. This series of photos documents the construction of the present MAMBO building and the installation of several key exhibitions.
forWhatContent: Museums are democratising, inclusive and polyphonic spaces for critical dialogue about pasts and futures. Acknowledging and addressing the conflicts and challenges of the present, they hold artefacts and specimens in trust for society, safeguard diverse memories for future generations and guarantee equal rights and equal access to heritage for all people. Museums are not for profit. They are participatory and transparent, and work in active partnership with and for diverse communities to collect, preserve, research, interpret, exhibit, and enhance understandings of the world, aiming to contribute to human dignity and social justice, global equality and planetary wellbeing. (Icom, 2019)
proposal: Museums are democratising, inclusive and polyphonic spaces for critical dialogue about pasts and futures. Acknowledging and addressing the conflicts and challenges of the present, they hold artefacts and specimens in trust for society, safeguard diverse memories for future generations and guarantee equal rights and equal access to heritage for all people. Museums are not for profit. They are participatory and transparent, and work in active partnership with and for diverse communities to collect, preserve, research, interpret, exhibit, and enhance understandings of the world, aiming to contribute to human dignity and social justice, global equality and planetary wellbeing. (Icom, 2019)
questions: Why was the creation of MAMBO important for the modernisation of Colombia?
How do museums help us understand the world?
What does it mean to be democratic, inclusive and polyphonic?
Why do museums want to safeguard diverse memories for future generations?
How can a museum contribute to human dignity, social justice and planetary wellbeing?
didYouKnow: Did you know the collection of the Bogotá Museum of Modern Art MAMBO numbers over 4500 works of art, forming part of Colombia’s cultural heritage.
activity: Design and make your own museum out of paper and show it to your class.

keyConcepts.title: Curatorship
keyConcepts.content: The practice of selecting and organising a series of artworks into an exhibition according to a predefined thematic framework.

img.alt: 1978. Eduardo Serrano junto a la escultura 'Toro de lidia' de Maria Cristina Franco. Montaje del IV Salón Atenas. Fotografía de Oscar Monsalve.

keyConcepts.title: Museography
keyConcepts.content: Discipline dealing with development of techniques and methods in the running of a museum, primarily the architectural and spatial features of temporary exhibitions and permanent collection.

img.alt: 1981. Installing ‘Yellows and Reds’, by Pedro Ramos for VII Salón Atenas. Photo: Oscar Monsalve.

keyConcepts.title: Cultural Heritage
keyConcepts.content: A set of tangible and intangible attributes making up the memory and identity of a human group, and which has a symbolic, historic and economic value.

img.alt: 1983. Third floor of present building under construction. Photo: Oscar Monsalve.

keyConcepts.title: Collection
keyConcepts.content: A set of material products of a culture forming part of an institution dedicated to the preservation of its heritage. In museums of anthropology these may be objects such as tools and clothing; in art museums, paintings and sculptures.

img.alt: 1981. Works by Mónica Negret and Pedro Ramos at VII Salón Atenas. Photo: Oscar Monsalve.

keyConcepts.title: Democracy
keyConcepts.content: A system of government by the entire population of a state, where decisions are taken collectively and which seeks the guaranteed participation of the majority.

img.alt: 1982. Children during an educational workshop, with Daniel Castro. Photo: Oscar Monsalve

keyConcepts.title: Museum Education
keyConcepts.content: Sector that promotes learning inside the museum, studies its community, and designs teaching activities and programmes aimed at members of the public.

img.alt: 982. Auditorium of Museum of Modern Art. Photo: Oscar Monsalve.

img1.alt: 1979. Hoarding marking launch of first phase of building work at present site. Photo: Oscar Monsalve.

title: Modern Art and the world.
historyDescription:
Modern Art was a process during which painters, sculptors and writers sought out novel forms of representation. The modern period in art is usually described as occurring between 1850 – 1970. The industrial revolutions of nineteenth century Europe and the violent upheavals inspired by the 1789 Revolution in France, all contributed to the modern movement. Artists rebelled against academic art with its Renaissance preoccupations; religion, Greek mythology, and the traditional genres of portrait and still life, preferring to explore individual interests and problems in their work (Gallerix, 2009).

 In the 1830s the invention of photography caused a break with the tradition of figurative representation and led artists to create work according to a personal aesthetic. The work of the European vanguards exemplifies formal and conceptual explorations made by artists of this period as they experimented with new subjects, materials, techniques and processes, pushing the boundaries of what was understood as “art”. (Academia Play, 2016).
author: Edouard Manet
authorContent: Édouard Manet (Paris, France, 1832-1883). Forerunner of impressionism and modern painting. This painting caused controversy for its depiction of a nude woman who appears to be a sex worker, challenging contemporary morality and traditional portrayals of the nude in art.
forWhatContent: The rebellious roots of modern art.
didYouKnow: Did you know the advent of photography radically altered the way we see the world. It brought about great changes in the image-making process and the materiality of works of art.
questions: Why was it important for the artists of the time to question classical ideals of beauty?
Why does a creative artist need to rebel and ask questions?
Why do we need areas where we can use our right to free expression?

keyConcepts.title: Academism
keyConcepts.content: Artistic current emerging from the Paris Academy of Fine Arts at the start of the nineteenth century and which looks back to art of the classical period. Also known as Neoclassicism; it is a romantic and idealist movement, linking art to ideas of beauty, perfection and technical skill.

img.alt: Ricardo Acevedo Bernal. Model in Paris, 1889. Source: MAMBO Collection.

keyConcepts.title: Vanguards
keyConcepts.content: Early twentieth century antiacademic and experimental art movements, emerging out of the First World War and its aftermath. Cubism, Dadaism and Futurism all influenced the birth of modern art.

img.alt: Salvador Dalí. Venus of the Head of Roses. Undated. Source MAMBO Collection.

keyConcepts.title: Abstract Art
keyConcepts.content: Refers to artworks that do not represent any part of their subjects in a precise way.

img.alt: Amelia Peláez. Untitled, 1967. Source: MAMBO Collection.

keyConcepts.title: Figurative Art
keyConcepts.content: Refers to artworks that represent images, objects and scenes from life in a realistic and recognisable way.

img.alt: Liliana Porter. Tear. 1974. Source: MAMBO Collection.

proposal: The rebellious roots of modern art.

img1.alt: Édouard Manet. Olympia. 1863. Oil on canvas. Source: Wikimedia Foundation under licence C.C. BY 2.0.
img1.caption: Édouard Manet (Paris, France, 1832-1883). Forerunner of impressionism and modern painting. This painting caused controversy for its depiction of a nude woman who appears to be a sex worker, challenging contemporary morality and traditional portrayals of the nude in art.

img2.alt: Camille Claudel. The Age of  Maturity. 1899. Bronze. Source: Wikimedia Commons under GNU free documentation licence.
img2.caption: Camille Claudel (Fère-en-Tardenois, France, 1864-1943). One of the pioneers of modern sculpture in her opposition to the French Academy. In this highly symbolic work, Claudel shows her interest in themes other than the canonical glorification of beauty and perfection.

img3.alt: Pablo Picasso. Les Demoiselles d’Avignon. 1907. Oil on Canvas. Source: Wikimedia Commons under licence C.C. BY 2.0. Collection of New York Museum of Modern Art (Moma).
img3.caption: Pablo Picasso (Malaga, Spain, 1881-1973). Probably the most celebrated of all modern artists for his defiance of form and use of   distortion. The iconic work, Les Demosielles d’Avignon, was the first painting to feature physical distortion and geometric abstraction as a new procedure in painting, qualities which would later develop into Cubism.

didYouKnowImg.alt: Nicéphore Niépce. Untitled. 1826. Source: Wikimedia Commons in the public domain.

questionImg.alt: Michelangelo. David. 1501-1504, Gallery of the Academy of Florence. Source: Wikimedia Commons under licence CC BY 3.0

title: Modern Art in Colombia
historyDescription:
In Colombia, the first examples of modernist painting start to appear during the early years of the twentieth century. Artists taking on the legacy of Dadaism and cubism searched for new forms in painting and sculpture as an escape from the traditional aesthetic of beauty.

 Colombia was also a scenario for the global debate between capitalism and communism, and the drive for change led artists to question established moral principles in politically transgressive artworks. A desire to uncouple Colombian art history from the European tradition, inspired the “Bachué” group of artists to explore the imagery and symbols of local indigenous and rural communities.

 From the 1950s onwards, influenced by political events such as El Bogotazo, artists adopted a firm political stance, clearly seen in the confrontation between the defenders of socialist realism and the maintenance of a separate identity, and the supporters of abstract expressionism. This clash between abstraction and figurative art had a decisive influence on the origins of contemporary art in the country (Jaramillo, 2012, pp. 129-206).
author: Beatriz Daza
authorContent: Beatriz Daza (Pamplona, Colombia, 1927-1968) was a ceramist and painter, pioneer of assemblages and experimentation in the use of the canvas as support for a variety of objects. This work is one of her representations of domestic spaces as fragmented still-life composition.
forWhatContent: Art in its political context, and the need for a national discourse in the face of foreign influence.
didYouKnow: Did you know the period of fighting between Liberals and Conservatives in Colombia, known as La Violencia, drove artists to protest against the social and political situation.
activity: Research your own family tree, pinpoint your family origins and facial features. Draw a face or design a logo to represent your family, and explain why.
questions: What are the ideological differences between socialist realism and abstract expressionism?
How would you define national identity? What modern and traditional values do you see in your own family?
Since not everyone shares the same morals, beliefs and values, how do we arrive at a consensus and avoid violence?
proposal: Art in its political context, and the need for a national discourse in the face of foreign influence.

keyConcepts.title: Cold War
keyConcepts.content: Political, military and cultural confrontation lasting from 1945 – 1989 between capitalist Western powers, led by the United States, and communist Soviet Union.

img.alt: Unknown author. Photograph of the Berlin Wall. 1989. Source: Wikimedia Commons under GNU licence.

keyConcepts.title: El Bogotazo
keyConcepts.content: Eruption of rioting and violence in Bogota, triggered by the assassination of presidential candidate Jorge Eliécer Gaitán on 9 April 1948, giving rise to the period of fighting between Liberal and Conservative parties known as La Violencia.

img.alt: Sady González. Burning Tram. 1948. Source: MAMBO Collection. REG 2825

keyConcepts.title: Socialist Realism
keyConcepts.content: Artistic style developed in the Soviet Union during the 1920s, aimed at an ideologically motivated representation of reality, often with the intention of denouncing supposed anti-Soviet tendencies. Influential in the creation of Latin American movements, for whom socialist realism was a weapon in the fight against imperialism.

img.alt: Unknown author. Monument to combatants in the October Revolution. Almaty, Kasakhstan. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public licence.

keyConcepts.title: North American Expressionism (Abstract Expressionism)
keyConcepts.content: Considered USA’s first abstract art movement. Pictorial works on large canvases onto which paint has been spattered in a spontaneous manner, creating free, expressive images. Abstract expressionism stood in opposition to socialist realism, and was used during the Cold War to propagate ideas associated with capitalism.

img.alt: Jackson Pollock. Head. 1938-1941. Source: Wikimedia Commons under licence CC BY 2.0.

keyConcepts.title: Communism
keyConcepts.content: Economic system proposed by Karl Marx; in which private property is eliminated and goods produced by the workers are distributed equally, and where the state controls the means of production.

img.alt: John Jabez Edwin Mayall. Portrait of Karl Marx. 1875. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public licence.

keyConcepts.title: Capitalism
keyConcepts.content: Economic system put forward by Adam Smith; in which capital generated through workers’ labour belongs to an individual or private company, driving a market economy and creating socio-economic division.

img.alt: Unknown Author. Portrait of Adam Smith. 1800. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public licence.

img1.alt: Beatriz Daza. Two Yellow Days. 1966. Porcelain, glass, ceramic, plaster and metal on wood. Source: MAMBO Collection.
img1.caption: Beatriz Daza (Pamplona, Colombia, 1927-1968) was a ceramist and painter, pioneer of assemblages and experimentation in the use of the canvas as support for a variety of objects. This work is one of her representations of domestic spaces as fragmented still-life composition.

img2.alt: Alejandro Obregón. Violence. 1962. Obregón. Hernán Díaz. Source: MAMBO Collection.
img2.caption: Alejandro Obregón (Barcelona, Spain, 1920-1992), came to this country at the age of six. He was a member of the Barranquilla Group and an important figure in Colombian modern and contemporary painting. He combines figuration and abstraction in his paintings (figurative expressionism), which display expressive brushstrokes and patches of colour.  This work shows Obregón’s preoccupation with denouncing harsh realities in Colombia.

img3.alt: Edgar Negret. Face of Christ. 1949. Wood and steel: MAMBO Collection.
img3.caption: Edgar Negret (Popayán, Colombia, 1920-2012). One of Colombia’s most influential sculptors. By incorporating materials denoting modernity into his work such as iron, aluminium and wood, he brings into question ideas of the industrial and the natural. This piece represents a figure from Colombian religious culture, but in an abstract manner.

didYouKnowImg.alt: Sady González. Corpses in a cemetery, 9th April, Bogotá. 1948. Source: MAMBO Collection.

questionImg.alt: León Ruiz. Untitled. 1981. Source: MAMBO Collection.

activityImg.alt: Gertjan Bartelsman. Floralba. 1976. Source: MAMBO Collection.

title: Conceptual Art in the world.
historyDescription:
Conceptual Art (also known as Conceptualism), has its beginnings during the 1960s and consists in recognising art not only for its aesthetic qualities, but also for its intellectual significance. Conceptual art does not use one medium in particular, as it does not rely on form, but on content and the ability to communicate an idea. For this reason, it may take different forms: installation, photography, readymade, performance, graphic work or video art.

 Conceptual artists are interested in context. They take a theme and confer new meanings on objects, images and concepts through their work. With Land Art for example, an interest in space has led artists to alter the landscape and make use of available materials. Minimalism, on the other hand, makes no attempt to represent an outside reality, “what you see is what you see” (Tate, s. f.). 

 During the 1960s and 1970s great social changes were brought about through activism on the part of various movements: Feminist, LGBT, and antiracist movements, protests against the Vietnam War and the May 1968 demonstrations in Paris.
 Conceptual art often pinpoints and denounces social, political, religious or ecological problems, with frequent use of irony and satire. It also questions the significance of art itself, asserting that what is “art” is subjectively determined by the artist themselves, while the spectator completes the work with their own interpretation (EcuRed, 2019).
author: Cildo Merireles
authorContent: Cildo Meireles (Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 1948) is an artist recognised for his contribution to conceptual art in Latin America, through works based on an analysis of Latin American political and economic systems. Here he uses a series of fake Brazilian banknotes to generate reflection around capital, power, and exploitation.
questions: What is the significance of content over form?
In your opinion, what is and is not art?
What research methods do artists use?

keyConcepts.title: Counterculture
keyConcepts.content: Counterculture refers to values and modes of behaviour that are opposed to those established by a society. The term first appears in a 1968 book by historian Theodore Roszak, who uses “counterculture” to describe the beat generation, the hippie movement, the sexual revolution and the pacifist movements of the United States.

img.alt: Mark Goff. Woodstock Festival opening ceremony. 1969. Source: Wikimedia Commons under public licence.

keyConcepts.title: Context
keyConcepts.content: Array of physical, sociopolitical and cultural conditions surrounding an object or event. Context determines the purpose, customs and values of a particular human group.

img.alt: Carlos Caicedo. Bogotá, 1975. Source: MAMBO collection.

keyConcepts.title: Aesthetics
keyConcepts.content: A philosophical discipline that studies the perception, sensations and criteria involved in our judgement of beauty and taste in art.

img.alt: Francisco Antonio Cano. Still Life. 1912. Source: MAMBO Collection.

img1.alt: Cildo Meireles. Zero Cruzeiro. 1974. Lithograph. Source: MAMBO Collection.
img1.caption: Cildo Meireles (Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 1948) is an artist recognised for his contribution to conceptual art in Latin America, through works based on an analysis of Latin American political and economic systems. Here he uses a series of fake Brazilian banknotes to generate reflection around capital, power, and exploitation.

img2.alt: Andy Warhol. Campbell's Soup Cans. 1962. Special edition. 2015. Source: Wikimedia Commons under Creative Commons licence Attribution 3.0 Unported.
img2.caption: Andy Warhol (Pittsburg, USA, 1928-1987) was one of the pioneers of Pop Art in the United States. Warhol used grocery products to reflect on consumerism and originality in art. In this well-known work, the artist copied the packaging of a product of mass consumption. He then reproduced it, marking consumerism as a contemporary way of life, and posing the question:  can any object can be considered art?

img3.alt: Nancy Holt. Sun Tunnels. 1976. Cement tubes with drilled holes. Source: Wikimedia Commons under licence C.C. 2.0.
img3.caption: Nancy Holt (Worcester, USA, 1938-2014) is one of the first artists to find new ways of viewing the landscape through transdisciplinary works. In this piece, characteristic of Land Art and Minimalism, she sets a group of cement tunnels with holes drilled in them onto a flat area of land. On the winter solstice, 21st December, the sun aligns with the tunnels and its light is reflected on their interior.

didYouKnowImg.alt: Marcel Duchamp. The Fountain. 1917. Fuente: Wikimedia Commons bajo dominio público.

questionImg.alt: Luis Camnitzer. Window with Landscape above Wallpapered Wall with Flowers.1968. Source: MAMBO Collection.
